awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Advancing Student Success in Undergraduate Engineering and Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims. This project at California State University-Fullerton will advance the aims of the HSI Program by increasing retention and graduation rates in computer science and engineering and reducing high repetition rates in lower-division STEM courses. Many students encounter challenges unique to their cultural or economic background, such as competing financial responsibilities and family commitments.  These challenges can decrease students' capacity to achieve their potential level of performance in college. This project seeks to generate new knowledge about the role of social support mechanisms in helping students overcome these challenges. To this end, the project aims to integrate sociocultural practices, establish strong student-faculty rapport, and involve students in intellectually stimulating, personally relevant learning experiences, and hands-on research experiences in lower-division bottleneck STEM courses. By increasing retention and graduation rates, HSIs such as California State University-Fullerton have a potential to help fill critical gaps and broaden participation in the US STEM workforce.

This project aims to develop contextualized, replicable learning modules; improve curricula and pedagogical approaches; provide faculty development and support; establish effective family and community engagement; and cultivate engaging faculty-student interactions. The learning modules may help researchers and educators in other higher education institutions, including HSIs, to adopt and enhance student learning in lower-division STEM courses. Involving students' families in STEM enrichment activities is predicted to create an enduring awareness in the community, with the potential to motivate future generations of students to pursue STEM careers. Both quantitative and qualitative research data will be collected and will include student outcomes and personal, social, cognitive, and contextual factors that may influence these outcomes. Anticipated student benefits from the project include improved morale, self-efficacy, persistence, and improvement in career-readiness skills, which are essential for the next-generation of scientists and engineers who will sustain the global competitiveness of the US economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advancing Student Success by Utilizing Relevant Social-Cultural and Academic Experiences (ASSURE-US)

California State University, Fullerton

Project Outcome Report

 Intellectual Merit

The ASSURE-US project at California State University, Fullerton, bolstered student success in Engineering and Computer Science. The multi-pronged effort included faculty development and support, contextual-based curriculum improvement in lower-division bottleneck courses, opportunities for faculty and student interactions, and early-stage undergraduate research experiences. Over the past five years, the project has developed, designed, and implemented four successful program components that directly impacted faculty and student participants. The impact included: 

  1. Faculty development and support using the ‘Engineering Design as Practice’ faculty support paradigm to structure workshops and module development for gateway courses, including Calculus and Introduction to Computer Science, while building faculty capacity.
  2. Module development to expand contextual-based learning and course relevancy in four gateway courses: 1) Calculus I, 2) Calculus II, 3) Introduction to Programming, and 4) Object-Oriented Programming.
  3. Student-teacher interaction councils designed to build rapport and facilitate communication among faculty and students, enable informal mentoring, help students learn about campus resources, and support high student motivation and enthusiasm toward academic pursuits.
  4. Six-week undergraduate summer research experiences structured as paid internships that paired students with faculty researchers to conduct hands-on research.

Broader Impacts

The ASSURE-US project positively impacted faculty and students in Engineering and Computer Science at CSUF. Through a range of reimagined and re-designed activities to address the challenges posed by the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic, the ASSURE-US project proved resilient to make a significant difference in the participants' academic, professional, and personal lives. Selected findings that had a broader impact on the faculty and students include: 

  1. Five faculty were supported through faculty development and support.
  2. Fifteen modules were developed for four gateway courses. Calculus modules engaged students in designing a roller coaster and learning the basics of integrations with airfoils. Computer Science modules engaged students in debugging, programming, and utilizing reference materials. The ASSURE-US project team developed various academic intervention modules for different Calculus and Computer Science courses, benefiting a total of 1,519 undergraduate students.
  3. Additionally, the project hosted 40 student-teacher interaction councils, covering topics such as campus resources workshops, stress management during exams, keeping motivation, study skill strategies, virtual coffee breaks with ECS faculty, and panels such as “In Conversation with a Software Engineer” or “Becoming a Computer Science Educator.” The net outcome of these efforts suggests that ASSURE-US participants were more likely to persist or graduate than non-ASSURE-US students.

Over five years, 219 undergraduate students participated in summer research experiences. Three students obtained a paid Science Undergraduate Laboratory Internship (SULI) with the Department of Energy. The research was conducted in person, virtually, and in a hybrid format. Some student researchers worked independently, while others worked in small groups, depending on the nature of the project and the preference of faculty advisors. Undergraduate researchers prepared posters highlighting project work and disseminated them through regional, national, and international conferences. Some participants also co-authored manuscripts with assistance from faculty and published their findings in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. The success of the ASSURE-US project is evidenced by various recognitions and media coverage the project has received over the years. In 2020, the ASSURE-US project video presentation on “Culturally inclusive practices for advancing student success in STEM” won national acclaim by winning first place in the National Science Foundation (NSF) STEM – Diversity Inclusion Video Exhibition Challenge, Experts’ Choice Award and People’s Choice Award. The video is posted at the NSF INCLUDES National Network and can be accessed by clicking the weblink: https://www.includesnetwork.org/blogs/nsf-includes-coordination-hub1/2020/10/06/innovative-stem-dive-video-series-showcases-creati. In 2021, the ASSURE-US project efforts were cited as evidence of effectiveness and intentionality in institutional practices serving Latino students for the prestigious Seal of Excelencia to CSUF. In 2022, academic and sociocultural intervention efforts were nominated for an Example of Excelencia in Education – a recognition that documents sustained efforts at promoting minority education. In 2023, the life story of one of the ASSURE-US student participants, Jose “Pepe” Tapia, was highlighted by Amazon: https://youtu.be/1luQMN2zWnw. His participation in the ASSURE-US summer research program was the catalyst that led him to his current research projects. At CSUF, his success story and ASSURE-US project supported summer research participation with the ASSURE-US project Co-PI Dr. Doina Bein was highlighted. https://news.fullerton.edu/2023/04/amazon-scholarship-recipient-discovers-the-power-of-artificial-intelligence/. ASSURE-US summer research experience participants had a mean graduation rate of 99% compared to 73% for non-participants (while controlling for initial GPA, Hispanic status, first-generation student status, and other ASSURE-US activities). Students reported having positive experiences, felt they contributed something of value to the projects, spent time doing real science, and were more committed to their majors after participating in the experience. In summary, the ASSURE-US project, as intended, has significantly affected the academic and personal lives of ASSURE-US participants. The enduring effect of the ASSURE-US project and its overall broader impact will undoubtedly continue beyond the five-year project duration.


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Sudarshan T Kurwadkar
